title: Hong Kong stocks gain the most in 2 weeks after Fed’s Powell hints at rate cut
description: China Evergrande, once the mainland’s top developer by sales, delisted after 16 years.
content:
The Hang Seng Index added 1.2 per cent to 25,642.70 at 9.50am local time, the biggest gain in two weeks. The Hang Seng Tech Index rose 1.8 per cent. On the mainland, the CSI 300 Index gained 0.8 per cent and the Shanghai Composite Index strengthened 0.6 per cent.

Mining firm Zijin Mining surged 5.1 per cent to HK$24.04 and chipmaker SMIC jumped 3 per cent to HK$58.55. Search-engine leader Baidu added 3.7 per cent to HK$88.85, online games provider NetEase climbed 3.3 per cent to HK$212 and e-commerce giant JD.com advanced 2.8 per cent to HK$124.80.

Sinopharm Group fell 1.3 per cent to HK$19.27, while Wuxi Biologics dropped 1 per cent to HK$32.60.

After Powell hinted at the Jackson Hole symposium on Friday that interest rates could head lower amid a softening jobs market, the S&P 500 rose 1.5 per cent higher, its best gain since May 27, and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite added 1.9 per cent.

China Group was delisted from the Hong Kong stock exchange on Monday, marking the end of a 16-year run for what was once the country’s largest developer by sales. The move underscores the deep crisis engulfing China’s property sector after the company defaulted on its debt in 2021. The company’s liabilities had snowballed to more than US$300 billion at its peak.
summary: The Hang Seng Index has risen by 1.2%, marking the largest gain in two weeks. The CSI 300 Index gained 0.8%, and the Shanghai Composite Index strengthened by 0.6%. Mining company Zijin Mining surged by 5.1%, while chipmaker SMIC jumped by 3.5%. The S&P 500 also rose by 1.,5%, while the Nasdaq Composite added 1.9%.
shortSummary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.2% after Fed chairman Powell suggested a potential interest rate cut, with notable gains across Asia including China and the US.

argos_summary: The Hang Seng Index rose 1.2% to 25,642.70, its biggest gain in two weeks, while the Hang Seng Tech Index climbed 1.8% and mainland indices CSI 300 and Shanghai Composite gained 0.8% and 0.6% respectively. Leading Hong Kong stocks such as Zijin Mining, SMIC, Baidu, NetEase and JD.com posted gains of 3–5%, whereas Sinopharm and Wuxi Biologics fell slightly. U.S. markets reacted to Fed Chair Jerome Powell’s hint that rates could ease, pushing the S&P 500 up 1.5% and the Nasdaq 1.9%. The article also notes the delisting of China Group (Evergrande) from the Hong Kong exchange after a 16‑year run, underscoring the deep crisis in China’s property sector amid mounting debt.
